headline.main: THE GREAT REBELLION.; Highly Important News from Western Virginia. Attack by Floyd on the Position of Gen. Rosecrans. FIGHTING ALL DAY ON FRIDAY. CESSATION OF FIRING ON SATURDAY. BAD POSITON OF FLOYD. Gen. Rosecrans Making Preparations to Surround Him. Capture of Prestonburgh, Ky., by the National Troops. Another Successful Skirmish in Missouri. Favorable News from the Great Fleet. AFFAIRS AT THE NATIONAL CAPITAL. SPECIAL DISPATCH FROM WASHINGTON. THE GREAT EXPEDITION. ADDITIONAL NEWS FROM BELOW. THE RISE IN THE POTOMAC. VICTIMS OF THE BALL'S BLUFF DISASTER. BURNING OF THE GENERAL HOSPITAL. GENERALS SMITH AND LANDER THE MARYLAND ELECTION. RELIEF NEEDED FOR MISSOURI SOLDIERS. AN ODD SPECULATION. ANOTHER REVIEW. THE FEMALE PRISON AGAIN. A COURT OF INQUIRY. THE PROVOST COURT IN ALEXANDRIA. NEW MAIL ARRANGEMENTS. HEALTH OF THE NEW-YORK THIRTY-EIGHTH. ENLISTMENT SWINDLES. A SEAMAN'S FUNERAL. RETURNED TO WASHINGTON. SUTHER'S EXPEDIENTS. THE FIRST FIRE ZOUAVES. RECOGNIZED. REVIEW OF GEN. SEDGEWICK'S BRIGADE.

docs.lead_paragraph: SAMUEL K. HALL, Adjutant of the Twentyseventh Regiment of Missouri Volunteers, is in Washington, to obtain relief for the men of that regiment and their families. headline.main: THE GREAT REBELLION.; AFFAIRS AT THE NATIONAL CAPITAL. More Rumors About the Removal of Fremont. No Change on the Upper or Lower Potomac. The Great Expedition Heard From Off Hatteras on Wednesday Night, with Fine Weather. PROBABLE ARRIVAL AT ITS DESTINATION The Journey of Gen. Scott from Washington to New-York. Enthusiastic Reception at Harrisburgh. IMPORTANT NEWS FROM MISSOURI The Rebel Army Thirty Thousand Strong, at Neosho. THE REPORTED REMOVAL OF GEN. FREMONT. GEN. M'CLELLAN. RUNNING THE POTOMAC BLOCKADE. SHELLING THE NATIONAL INTRENCHMENTS. MARYLAND'S LOYALTY. CAMP COMFORTS. AN EQUESTRIENNE ON THE OUTPOSTS. THE CONDITION OF FAIRFAX COUNTY THE RUIN INFLICTED BY THE WAR. A RESIGNATION AND AN APPOINTMENT. NO BOUNTY LANDS. THE PACIFIC TELEGRAPH. PREPARATIONS FOR QUARTERING SOLDIERS PROBABLE EFFECT OF THE GREAT EXPEDITION ON THE SOUTH A DIVERSION TO BE AVAILED OF.

docs.lead_paragraph: There seems to be little doubt that, nearly a week ago, a special messenger left Washington with a letter to Gen. FREMONT, ordering him to transfer his command to Gen. HUNTER until a successor shall be specially designated. [We have good reason to believe that such a letter as the one spoken of by our correspondent has been prepared, but that it has or will be forwarded is not so certain. ED. TIMES.]

docs.snippet: The correspondent of the London Herald, in a letter dated Washington, Sept. 26, gives some interesting particulars of observations made at Norfolk and Portsmouth, through which places he passed while on the way from Richmond to Washington. He writes:

headline.main: THE WAR IN THE WEST.; AFFAIRS IN MISSOURI. GEN. FREMONT'S ADVANCE A RECONNOISSANCE BY GEN. ASBOTH. Correspondence of the St. Louis Republican. THE CHARGE OF FREMONT'S BODY GUARD. OFFICIAL REPORT OF THE RECAPTURE OF LEXINGTON. PRICES MOVEMENTS. GEN. LANE'S BRIGADE. AFFAIRS IN KENTUCKY. QUESTION OF NEGRO EMANCIPATION.

docs.lead_paragraph: A patient endurance of monotonous routine is as much a soldier's duty as gallantry upon the field, so that an occasional approach to the actual dangers of his career carries with it an inspiriting relief. The march of Gen. FREMONT from St. Louis presents little more than that systematic attention to military detail, which constitutes the ordinary precursor to the conflict.
